source_paper: Sobotkova et al. (2023) - Creating large, high-quality geospatial datasets from historical maps using novice volunteers

overall_summary.assessment_scope: Complete verification of all extracted items and relationships
overall_summary.overall_assessment: Excellent extraction quality with only minor issues in claims accuracy

pass_a_accuracy_detailed.summary: Overall accuracy 94.1% - Strong performance with isolated issues in claims

research_designs.notes: RD-IMP-001 has minor data quality issue (trigger_locations contains duplicate entries)

errors_identified.description: Second half of compound claim extracted without comparative context from first half
errors_identified.verbatim_source: Crowdsourcing scales better than direct digitisation by experts, but requires an appropriate platform and the technical skills to adapt it.
errors_identified.issue: C004 extracts 'but' clause without 'Crowdsourcing scales better' context, creating incomplete comparative statement

errors_identified.description: Claim text attributes lack of GIS skills to volunteers, but verbatim quote references 'volunteers often lack skills' from literature review, not TRAP project findings
errors_identified.verbatim_source: Volunteers often lack the skills necessary to use GIS software (Elwood, 2008b; Jones & Weber, 2012; Owen et al., 2009).
errors_identified.issue: Generic literature statement about volunteers misrepresented as empirical finding about TRAP volunteers. Should be theoretical/literature claim, not empirical claim about project volunteers
errors_identified.corrective_action: Change claim_type from 'empirical' to 'theoretical' or reword to 'Literature indicates volunteers often lack GIS skills'

errors_identified.description: Claim presents authorial interpretation of student preferences as empirical observation
errors_identified.verbatim_source: Fifth, student volunteers are accustomed to, and even prefer, 'slippy-map', touch-screen interfaces on mobile devices over the point-and-click, desktop UI idiom.
errors_identified.issue: Source states preference as authorial assertion without empirical measurement. Should be claim_nature: 'interpretive' not 'descriptive'

errors_identified.description: Claim incorrectly states GIS features were hidden 'or eliminated' - source only mentions hiding
errors_identified.verbatim_source: GIS features not needed for digitisation were hidden or eliminated.
errors_identified.issue: Quote found on p.6 but discusses preprocessing/setup delegation to staff, not UI feature hiding. 'Hidden or eliminated' language found but in different context about expert workflow allocation, not volunteer UI simplification
errors_identified.corrective_action: Verify exact source location and ensure claim accurately reflects whether features were hidden in UI vs eliminated from workflow

errors_identified.description: Location states page 4, but verbatim quote found on page 5
trigger_locations array contains duplicate entries for '4. Discussion, 4.1, p9, para 1-2'

pass_b_granularity_detailed.summary: Overall granularity 99.3% - Excellent editorial judgment with appropriate consolidation

notable_consolidations: E002: Total time + breakdown (57 staff + 184 volunteer)
E044: Complex omissions data across two seasons
E065: Staff vs programmer time breakdown

issues_identified.description: Partial extraction of compound claim without comparative context
issues_identified.explanation: C004 extracts second clause ('but requires platform and skills') without first clause ('Crowdsourcing scales better'). Should either include full comparative statement or be two separate claims with clear relationship

key_findings: No over-splitting detected - strong editorial judgment on consolidation
Evidence extraction exemplary (100%) with excellent consolidation decisions
RDMAP hierarchy (Design→Method→Protocol) crystal clear and consistently maintained
Consistent detail levels within types (velocities, times, counts, observations)
Functional appropriateness maintained - granularity supports transparency and replicability assessment

pass_c_mapping_detailed.summary: Overall mapping quality 99.1% - Excellent relationship integrity

issues_identified.description: Low volunteer attrition (E041) supports satisfaction but only indirectly supports claim that volunteers could attain and maintain high digitisation rate
issues_identified.impact: Non-critical - C044 has strong alternative support from E055 (fastest digitisers: 44-45s/feature with low errors)
issues_identified.recommendation: Consider adding E033 or E034 as additional direct evidence for digitisation rate maintenance

key_findings: No structural mapping errors - all relationship types correctly aligned
Quantitative claims consistently supported by direct measurements
Comparative claims supported by explicit benchmark calculations
All threshold claims (C008, C055, C063, C064) have calculation evidence
Only 1 weak mapping identified, and claim remains well-supported through alternative evidence

priority_corrections.action: Change claim_type from 'empirical' to 'theoretical' OR reword claim_text to clarify this references literature, not TRAP project findings
priority_corrections.rationale: Incorrect categorisation - presents literature review statement as empirical project finding
priority_corrections.impact: Moderate - affects interpretation of evidence basis and claim role in argument

priority_corrections.action: Extract complete compound claim OR split into two related claims with explicit linkage
priority_corrections.rationale: Partial extraction loses comparative context essential to claim meaning
priority_corrections.impact: Moderate - flagged in both Pass A (context error) and Pass B (under-split)

priority_corrections.action: Verify source location and ensure 'hidden or eliminated' accurately reflects UI simplification vs workflow delegation
priority_corrections.rationale: Possible conflation of different aspects of expert/volunteer division of labor
priority_corrections.impact: Moderate - affects accuracy of technical implementation description

priority_corrections.action: Change claim_nature from 'descriptive' to 'interpretive' AND update location.page from 4 to 5
priority_corrections.rationale: Preference statement is authorial interpretation, not measured empirical observation
priority_corrections.impact: Minor - minor categorisation refinement + location correction

priority_corrections.action: Remove duplicate entries from trigger_locations array

patterns_identified.description: Methods, protocols, and research designs show perfect accuracy (100%) and perfect granularity (100%)
patterns_identified.significance: RDMAP framework successfully applied with clear hierarchy maintenance and appropriate abstraction levels

patterns_identified.description: Evidence items show perfect accuracy (100%), perfect granularity (100%), and near-perfect mapping (98.9%)
patterns_identified.significance: Quantitative measurements, calculations, and observations extracted with high precision and appropriate consolidation

patterns_identified.description: Claims show lower accuracy (88.4%) compared to other types, with all errors concentrated in claims
patterns_identified.significance: Claims extraction is more challenging due to need to: (1) distinguish empirical vs theoretical, (2) capture complete context for compound statements, (3) accurately categorise claim nature (descriptive vs interpretive)

patterns_identified.description: Multiple evidence items appropriately consolidated (E002, E028, E044, E065, E069, E072) without over-splitting
patterns_identified.significance: Strong editorial discretion in balancing atomic principle with functional usefulness

patterns_identified.description: All Pass A errors are categorisation/context/attribution issues - no fabricated content
patterns_identified.significance: Extraction process maintained high fidelity to source paper without introducing false information

patterns_identified.description: Only 1 item (C004) flagged in multiple passes; all other issues are independent
patterns_identified.significance: No systematic cascading errors - issues are isolated and localised

patterns_identified.description: 99.1% mapping quality with only 1 weak (not incorrect) relationship
patterns_identified.significance: Claim-evidence linkages, RDMAP hierarchy, and protocol-method connections well-maintained

strengths: Perfect RDMAP extraction (methods, protocols, designs): 100% accuracy, 100% granularity
Perfect evidence extraction: 100% accuracy, 100% granularity, excellent consolidation judgment
Excellent relationship mapping: 99.1% with no incorrect mappings
No hallucinations or confabulations - all errors are categorisation/context issues
Strong editorial judgment on consolidation vs atomic principle balance
All quantitative claims supported by direct measurement evidence
weaknesses: Claims accuracy (88.4%) lower than other types due to categorisation and context challenges
One compound claim (C004) under-split, losing comparative context
One literature claim (C018) miscategorised as empirical finding
Minor location and categorisation refinements needed for 2 claims (C028, C032)
recommendations: Priority 1: Fix C018 misattribution (literature vs empirical)
Priority 2: Re-extract C004 with full comparative context or split with explicit linkage
Address remaining minor issues (C028, C032 categorisation/location corrections)
Consider adding E033/E034 as additional evidence for C044 (currently weak link to E041)
Extraction process is production-ready with minor refinements
overall_assessment.fitness_for_use: Suitable for research transparency and replicability assessment with minor corrections. RDMAP and evidence components are production-ready. Claims require targeted corrections (5 items) but overall quality is excellent.
